results.content: I'm lost. There are no continuity in the coding from previous discussion to the next.

response.content: Sorry Elvin, you are probably in the theoretical lectures. Nowhere, even in the official documentation you have no continuity in coding examples. You can not simply copy and paste and expect it to work (this works in practical part of the course where I'm creating real application step by step from scratch). You have to think a little bit, I mean you need to clean your code from previous coding example. Can you provide more information, what you have problem with? I will try my best to help you in QA section of the course. And I hope you will change your review. Thank's!

results.content: Quite instructional until now. It started slowly, but that's very good for those who had no contact with Symfony. Some references to Unit of Work pattern when talking about EntityManager and more reference regarding Dependency Injection/Inversion of Control would be nice for those that want to dig up a little bit more from the abstractions behind the implementation.

Some references to Unit of Work pattern when talking about EntityManager and more reference regarding Dependency Injection/Inversion of Control would be nice for those that want to dig up a little bit more from the abstractions behind the implementation.

results.content: This tutorial helped me to understand some Symfony concepts and development workflow. However, terrible English pronunciation and broken grammar make it very difficult to listen to this. Also, in my opinion, the author is using bad programming practices here and there.

results.content:
It is a great course that covers plenty of topics. It helped me a lot to understand how to work with Symfony.

I have decent knowledge of php, I am working on a custom framework for more than 4 years.
I started firstly to learn Symfony from their written documentation, thus I knew a little how it works before I get into this course.

The only thing not that nice about the course is that some lessons were not ordered chronologically or the author reverted or added  pieces of code, actions that you are not warned about. 
This means that you have to stop an think about what you are doing and what to do to make things work, which most of the times is a great way to consolidate the knowledge.

Good course if you are a patient person.
results.content_html:
It is a great course that covers plenty of topics. It helped me a lot to understand how to work with Symfony.

I have decent knowledge of php, I am working on a custom framework for more than 4 years.
I started firstly to learn Symfony from their written documentation, thus I knew a little how it works before I get into this course.

The only thing not that nice about the course is that some lessons were not ordered chronologically or the author reverted or added pieces of code, actions that you are not warned about.
This means that you have to stop an think about what you are doing and what to do to make things work, which most of the times is a great way to consolidate the knowledge.

Good course if you are a patient person.

results.content:
Very thorough and well made content. I especially love the API part which was exactly what I need. 

However Symfony world is changing fast and some of the things shown in the course don't work anymore this way on the newer versions (I have not been able to install the versions used in this course). I spent a lot of time on the docs pages trying to figure out how the newer versions work (especially Easy Admin which has seen radical changes since this course was made).

Thank you Robert.
results.content_html:
Very thorough and well made content. I especially love the API part which was exactly what I need.

However Symfony world is changing fast and some of the things shown in the course don't work anymore this way on the newer versions (I have not been able to install the versions used in this course). I spent a lot of time on the docs pages trying to figure out how the newer versions work (especially Easy Admin which has seen radical changes since this course was made).

Thank you Robert.

results.content: In my opinion a great course with a lot of knowledge. Author knows a lot. Sometimes things switched in use cases and you have to rethink do same tasks in different way. The JS part is not the best part (I would use REACT or maybe just POSTMAN) but explains how it works. This course is very good for beginners to collect basic knowledge and I would recommend to go further and learn some design patterns or build a bigger project with less native JS, more concentrating on API + JS Framework (REACT). Also would be nice to see some more komplex ORM Queries. I've missed Criteria Expressions, Hydrate Modes etc.. Doctrine related stuff was always handled by project requirements and should be explained in more detailed way. But in sum => Very good work! Just continue improving and adding knowlegde. Symfony will be always and in future number one PHP framework for enterprise (better salary) solutions!

response.content: Thank you very much David for your opinion!
response.content_html: Thank you very much David for your opinion!

results.content_html: In my opinion a great course with a lot of knowledge. Author knows a lot. Sometimes things switched in use cases and you have to rethink do same tasks in different way. The JS part is not the best part (I would use REACT or maybe just POSTMAN) but explains how it works. This course is very good for beginners to collect basic knowledge and I would recommend to go further and learn some design patterns or build a bigger project with less native JS, more concentrating on API + JS Framework (REACT). Also would be nice to see some more komplex ORM Queries. I've missed Criteria Expressions, Hydrate Modes etc.. Doctrine related stuff was always handled by project requirements and should be explained in more detailed way. But in sum => Very good work! Just continue improving and adding knowlegde. Symfony will be always and in future number one PHP framework for enterprise (better salary) solutions!

results.content: Prowadzący zamiast pisać kod, przekleja go ze schowka, przez co jest brak możliwości nadążać za kursem. Trzeba lekcje oglądać dwa razy i tracić czas na zrozumienie co sepleni.

response.content: Seplenienie to akurat nie mój problem z wymową - takie odzywki praktykuj u siebie w domu albo na podwórku, na którym się wychowałeś, a nie tutaj. Masz możliwość spowolnienia wideo w odtwarzaczu jeśli coś jest za szybko. W tym kursie jest tworzona zaawansowana aplikacja od zera - to oczywiste, że nie wszystko będzie pisane od deski do deski, bo kurs trwałby 200 godzin albo więcej. Wszystko jest tak zrobione, że jest zrozumiałe. Spójrz na pozytywne oceny - wystawili je ludzie, którzy byli w stanie "nadążać za kursem".

Highly recommended to anyone who wants to start coding with Symfony.

results.content: was the best symfony course that I have done, but I feel that I needed a previous course (which I had already done prior to this) to keep up with this one as I would have had many questions If I had never used symfony before. As we approach the last few sections, It becomes difficult to follow along because not everything I did worked the first time (luckily I already had previous experience with symfony so I was able to debug and fix mos of my problems). The final RabbitMQ section took hours to do because installing on windows is not as easy as installing on Linux. I had to read the windows documentation which didnt help much because I don't understand what  most of it means. I used chocolaty to install and get RabbitMQ working. Other than that, I learned so much in this course than I think I would have anywhere else. I only wish it was more windows friendly and there was explanations on stuff like "If you get this error, it might be because of x,y,z, so check those files." Thank you very much, you definitely know your stuff.

I had to read the windows documentation which didnt help much because I don't understand what most of it means. I used chocolaty to install and get RabbitMQ working. Other than that, I learned so much in this course than I think I would have anywhere else. I only wish it was more windows friendly and there was explanations on stuff like "If you get this error, it might be because of x,y,z, so check those files." Thank you very much, you definitely know your stuff.

results.content:
Very good course on Symfony. Part 3 is actually all you need to start working with the framework. Detailed sections on real industry examples are  also given. A couple of packages will not work the way it's described, you will have to tweak the settings. To be sure - don't use version 4.2, but 4.3, then you will have less problems.

The section on the Rest API was a bit disappointing - too much time is spent on Java Script code. The course is not about JS, so it would be much better to keep the section clear, using Postman for API requests.

In summary - recommended course for starting to work with Symfony.
results.content_html:
Very good course on Symfony. Part 3 is actually all you need to start working with the framework. Detailed sections on real industry examples are also given. A couple of packages will not work the way it's described, you will have to tweak the settings. To be sure - don't use version 4.2, but 4.3, then you will have less problems.

The section on the Rest API was a bit disappointing - too much time is spent on Java Script code. The course is not about JS, so it would be much better to keep the section clear, using Postman for API requests.

In summary - recommended course for starting to work with Symfony.

results.content:
First of all Thank you for creating such a great course. But I expect some basic thing like, the download material are just a single file and it is of not much use. In the download option zip should contain the whole project. Instead there is only one single file available. For example you have one bash file named tests.sh (Here I am unable to get the whole code and run the file as you have not showed the full file nor you have attached it for download as a zip). 
Also you don't write commands and just show us the already printed commands and do next next as if, it is a power point lecture.

response.content:
Hi, Sandeep. I'm glad you found this course great :), but can you correct your star rating? You just gave only one star :(.  For almost every lecture there are downloadable files to support you (if you don't want to write yourself then you can download files and paste it to the project - this is how this course is organized). Please do not mislead others that in the downloadable file there is only "tests.sh". There are many downloadable files which at the end result with entire project - if you follow each step (this is the main purpose of this course). Also please do not mislead others that this is a "power point" course. I'm creating real applications in this course in a very understandable way step by step with checking each step in the web browser. If you are not able to follow something - feel free to ask in QA section.

I hope you will get a lot from this course! ps. Can you improve your rating? Thanks!

results.content:
So far this tutorial has been excruciating to watch. There are some good things and I do learn a lot but I am not enjoying it much. I give you the list.

Cons:
	*  Sometimes hard to understand because of the accent and wrong choice of words.
	*  Little bit dry, not too exciting.
	*  Portfolio project does not look appealing to the eye.
	*  Squeezing way too much functionality in the application for just a tutorial. A lot of things are just duplicated. Copy pasted.
	*  Way of using the editor strange. Large font and spacing.
	*  Strange and unpleasant way of building the website. The website HTML is there already and we make it dynamic. Would prefer to have made it from scratch. Page by page, feature by feature, as you would in real life. Would be much better to understand.
	*  Outdated way of programming, not following any good coding standards.
	*  Not using good type hinting and phpdoc.

Pros:
	*  Covers a lot of materials
	*  Very knowledgeable
	*  You actually learn a lot
	*  Technically ok-ish portfolio project

response.content: Hello Saif. Thank you very much for your detailed review. I really appreciate it. I will try my best to explain you things that you consider as course issues that should be solved in your opinion. First of all I'm sorry for my accent, I'm constantly improving it (and speech also) but anyway I think I'm understandable quite well (anyone can check it by watching free videos). If I hadn't done "squeezing way too much functionality in the application" it wouldn't be "technically ok-ish portfolio project" as you wrote. When it comes to HTML and beauty of the main project - keep in mind that this is not html course but Symfony course. HTML is not built from scratch because other students would accuse me of wasting time for html since it is Symfony course. And exactly today someone pointed mi out that I used too much JavaScript which btw is not true. And you are wrong by saying that not building html from scratch is not real life thing. It exactly is in teams of programmers. Keep in mind that this is not full stack developer course neither front end developer course. In the industry there exist frontend developers, backend etc. This is backend focused course. When it comes to coding standards, I'm aware of it, I also recorded one video about that where I adviced students to follow your own company coding standards. Do you think that every company uses standards that you saw somewhere on the internet? You are wrong. In the past I worked for many companies. Another thing - this is not Vscode or any other code editor course. This course is not something like I sit down, turn on the camera and record what I do. I'm very well prepared for each lecture because I don't like courses like instructor says to much "yhmmm, I'm sorry, what did I miss here yhmm, let me scratch my head a bit" - of course such things are real life programming, but I create courses, not things like that, although I'm aware that some students like it. Of course I also try to explain some potential problems during development - but obviously not missing comma at the end of line for example. And thus do not focus on how the course was recorded, rather than on it's technical content. Also I don't remember where I duplicated or copy pasted code, maybe it exists but not a lot for sure. I hope you rethink your review and give a little more stars. Thank's again. Cheers.
response.content_html: Hello Saif. Thank you very much for your detailed review. I really appreciate it. I will try my best to explain you things that you consider as course issues that should be solved in your opinion. First of all I'm sorry for my accent, I'm constantly improving it (and speech also) but anyway I think I'm understandable quite well (anyone can check it by watching free videos). If I hadn't done "squeezing way too much functionality in the application" it wouldn't be "technically ok-ish portfolio project" as you wrote. When it comes to HTML and beauty of the main project - keep in mind that this is not html course but Symfony course. HTML is not built from scratch because other students would accuse me of wasting time for html since it is Symfony course. And exactly today someone pointed mi out that I used too much JavaScript which btw is not true. And you are wrong by saying that not building html from scratch is not real life thing. It exactly is in teams of programmers. Keep in mind that this is not full stack developer course neither front end developer course. In the industry there exist frontend developers, backend etc. This is backend focused course. When it comes to coding standards, I'm aware of it, I also recorded one video about that where I adviced students to follow your own company coding standards. Do you think that every company uses standards that you saw somewhere on the internet? You are wrong. In the past I worked for many companies. Another thing - this is not Vscode or any other code editor course. This course is not something like I sit down, turn on the camera and record what I do. I'm very well prepared for each lecture because I don't like courses like instructor says to much "yhmmm, I'm sorry, what did I miss here yhmm, let me scratch my head a bit" - of course such things are real life programming, but I create courses, not things like that, although I'm aware that some students like it. Of course I also try to explain some potential problems during development - but obviously not missing comma at the end of line for example. And thus do not focus on how the course was recorded, rather than on it's technical content. Also I don't remember where I duplicated or copy pasted code, maybe it exists but not a lot for sure. I hope you rethink your review and give a little more stars. Thank's again. Cheers.

results.content_html:
So far this tutorial has been excruciating to watch. There are some good things and I do learn a lot but I am not enjoying it much. I give you the list.

Cons:
* Sometimes hard to understand because of the accent and wrong choice of words.
* Little bit dry, not too exciting.
* Portfolio project does not look appealing to the eye.
* Squeezing way too much functionality in the application for just a tutorial. A lot of things are just duplicated. Copy pasted.
* Way of using the editor strange. Large font and spacing.
* Strange and unpleasant way of building the website. The website HTML is there already and we make it dynamic. Would prefer to have made it from scratch. Page by page, feature by feature, as you would in real life. Would be much better to understand.
* Outdated way of programming, not following any good coding standards.
* Not using good type hinting and phpdoc.

Pros:
* Covers a lot of materials
* Very knowledgeable
* You actually learn a lot
* Technically ok-ish portfolio project

results.content:
**edit 2020-06-10** I'm at lesson 137 now.

- code is not clean at all. Makes it really hard to follow, what he is about to do and why
- he get's a lot of errors while coding -> makes it really difficult to follow. That would be ok for live coding but not in a prerecorded course.
- you should not even start using a URL structure like '/category,id'  not even to simplify things
- backend and frontend development is always done at the same time, which is pretty much the opposite of what a programmer should do.
**end edit 2020-06-10**

+ a lot of content
+ teacher is a very experienced programmer
- sometimes hard to understand because of his accent (his english is good though)
- even though it's a symfony 4/5 course, some things don't work the same in symfony 5 anymore. Symfony 5 doc is always open while doing the course
- course structure is not always logical (Sometimes code from the lesson before is deleted, sometimes it's kept)
- a lot of times there should be more and better explanations (WHAT are we going to do, WHY are we going to that, HOW will it be achieved)
- examples used should be more simplified and then used in a more realistic content
- creating sample data should be done one way, e.g. using fixtures. Sometimes he writes data in a controller, so data is written, when opening the page for the first time, then deletes that code from the controller to continue the topic of the course part
- a lot of times he copy/pastes code or shows code in the terminal that is already executed.  That's hard to follow

response.content: Hello David. I'm not sure that your second version of your rating refers to my course. There is definitely very small number of errors while coding because I am well prepared for each lecture. All of your **edit 2020-06-10** is simply not true. About  **edit 2020-06-10** - I suggested in the course to make course apps in the same version as instructor did. And later follow the upgrade section. I admit that some of the stuff was sped up because otherwise this course would lat approximately 50 hours (I created very advanced app from scratch in this course).
response.content_html: Hello David. I'm not sure that your second version of your rating refers to my course. There is definitely very small number of errors while coding because I am well prepared for each lecture. All of your **edit 2020-06-10** is simply not true. I admit that some of the stuff was sped up because otherwise this course would lat approximately 50 hours (I created very advanced app from scratch in this course).

results.content:
Great and comprehensive Symfony course which shows most possibilities of great framework. There are some inconsistencies between Symfony 3 & 4 topic discussions (such as provided Cache recommendations was changed in last Symfony 4 minor release), and some other small issues here and there, but they can be forgiven (as the course contains a huge amount of information).

Another thing I want to say, that in our world, working as a Developer, you should always expect things to change quite often. Overall the course contains a lot of different interesting topics, and helps to build a global picture of Symfony components and how the real application should look like.

As for those, who complain about code styling and some other recommendation violations, I would suggest you to use other sources to make your code good, such as S.O.L.I.D., Design Patterns (GoF) and Programming Principles (KISS, YAGNI, DRY, SoC). Also, take a look at DDD concept, which is also an interesting topic.

response.content: Thank you for your nice words Vitaliy! Course update is coming soon - Rest API with API Platform for Symfony. Also I will think about what you wrote - design patterns etc.

Another thing I want to say, that in our world, working as a Developer, you should always expect things to change quite often. Overall the course contains a lot of different interesting topics, and helps to build a global picture of Symfony components and how the real application should look like.

As for those, who complain about code styling and some other recommendation violations, I would suggest you to use other sources to make your code good, such as S.O.L.I.D., Design Patterns (GoF) and Programming Principles (KISS, YAGNI, DRY, SoC). results.content:
I missed some brief explanation about some basic concepts of symfony. For example what is formbuilder, what orm asserts are, what is this expression language, what are those votes and why do i need them. Someone, who came from joomla or wordpress (or not used any framework before just knows the language), has never met such things before.

Also, the order of the lectures in the 3th section, could be improved.
Flash messages, cookies, session, right after we were talking about services and routes, I felt that point this part will be just some list of the features without any context. Maybe these lectures would have a better place after forms.
Functional test of emails, when we haven't talked about testing at all, also left strange.
Using security checker between lectures about login and authorization. It doesn't feel like it belongs there, it's about a different kind of security.

I think this course could be good for those who has already tried to understand symfony, but still doesn't feel comfortable with it (like me). I have high hopes for the 3th part, we'll see...

response.content:
Hello. Thank you for your opinion Robert :) I will think about customization of the order of the lectures. You write about theoretical introduction to Symfony, so this is exactly as you wrote - list of features but with some practical context to help you understand it better. Later you will have two practical parts of the course. I hope you will like it! From what I see you know the order at which you want to learn. This is exactly what table of contents is for - read it. When I mentioned about orm asserts for example, or other Symfony topics, mentioning about it wasn't my only job ;) I hope you know what it is as well as form builder etc.

If you have any additional questions, feel free to ask.

results.content:
This course is really in depth. Sometimes it rushes a little bit, but I could handle it.
What I really don’t like about it though, that it’s states that’s an Symfony 4&5 course but it’s actually a Symfony 4 course where at the end the upgrade is explained.
I bought this course because it said Symfony 4 and 5 and it’s simply not. Some stuff is not working the same in Symfony 5 anymore. I at least expected that it’s explained in the lectures how it’s done in both versions. For me this is actually false advertising but one can still learn a lot. 
And no, if it’s advertised for both versions, I don’t want to do the whole course in the old version.
This course needs definitely an update.

response.content: Some of the sections use Symfony 5. An update is coming soon. Hello.
response.content_html: Some of the sections use Symfony 5. An update is coming soon. Hello.

results.content: Linux OS ist schon mal der Anfang aller Probleme, da die Befehle für CMD ganz anders sind als die von Bash. Dann macht der Dozent gerne zwischen den Lektionen Dinge, die er nie erklärt aber trotzdem erwartet, dass man sie versteht... Er hat schon Ahnung von dem Unterrichtsstoff, aber die Vermittlung hapert extremst...
results.content_html: Linux OS ist schon mal der Anfang aller Probleme, da die Befehle für CMD ganz anders sind als die von Bash. Dann macht der Dozent gerne zwischen den Lektionen Dinge, die er nie erklärt aber trotzdem erwartet, dass man sie versteht... results.content:
My biggest frustrations with the course are, the instructor uses an extension for vscode that auto imports requirements in files and sometimes does not scroll up to show those things being imported. Also, he copies and pastes the code from his clipboard the majority of the class rather than typing it out. If he would type it out it would give the students a chance to type and keep up without having to continuously pause the video. Sometimes he doesn't show the entire files contents but just the part he's working on, so I have either assumed he kept the contents below and been wrong, or assumed he moved the contents below and been wrong, and you don't know until you download the lesson files which one he did, which is annoying to download, unzip, and open when it should just show in the lesson. 

The content so far is excellent. I have learned about all the major parts of Symfony, had a chance to work with them, and compare them to the project my team is doing at work and see how they implemented it. As I'm new to Symfony and it's a huge project, this course is saving me a lot of time of reading through documentation and trying to figure out all the features. 

TLDR: The course is worth the $, but it could be easily improved.

response.content: Hello, thanks. As  I remember I always showed what I imported. I created advanced app in this course from scratch. Without some techniques to speed up presenting it on the screen, this course would last approximately 50 hours and would be boring in my opinion. I hope you will rate this course better later and evaluate technical content much, rather than presentation layer.

results.content:
For now - 1 star - which seems one too much. Probably the only course on udemy without the option to download the project source code. For some strange reason the instructor decided to only add a single file for each lecture, so if you want to see the project and list dependencies or follow the final solution, or just skip some section, you are out of luck, you will be lost and unable to run the project... no one from the class has built the project and no one has provided the full project files (which is saying a lot already about it's usability...). 
Since you won't get the full project files, you won't be able to follow it properly, or go back and forth in lessons, or study the code...

response.content: Udemy offers you courses, this is not a marketplace where you can buy software. Please do not  mislead others, everyone can study the code, for each coding lecture I provided zipped file with code. There are a lot of happy students with this Symfony course. I hope you will understand this and change your rating, good luck!. Ps. Even some of the top Udemy instructors do not provide what you want - simply because Udemy offers courses, not software. Search github or envato market if you wish ready made software.
